moves.1. e4: This game starts a Najdorf sicilian.
moves.1... c5 2. Nf3 d6 3. d4 cxd4 4. Nxd4 Nf6: As usual I play the Najdorf. So far I haven't refrained from the Najdorf and only adopted other openings in speed play.
moves.6. Bg5: Bg5 - This promises a tough fight. He chooses the sharpest line.
moves.6... e6 7. Bc4: 7. Bc4 combined with Bg5 is unknown to me, though I have encountered it in speed games, but never looked it up in libraries or saw it in pros games.
moves.7... Be7: I decide to play the usual suspects.
moves.8. Qf3: This leaves the d4 knight unprotected and prevents f4. I feel relieved. Business stuff severely reduces my thinking time these days.
moves.8... Nc6: I know this is strange with a6 and no bishop or queen aside to take back on c6. So I have a battery of pawns on the 6th range "doing the same job". Still I opt for this to strengthen my center.
moves.9. Nxc6: Of course my opponent goes for this scenario.
moves.9... bxc6: An additional benefit is the newly opened b-file. Of course ...a6 was wasting time now.
moves.10. O-O-O: Still my rival is keen for double edged play. Now his rook is opposite my queen, attacking the d-pawn. But I feel one single center pawn is not enough.
moves.10... Qb6: Some calculation assures the d-pawn is poisoned. So I can forcefully develope my queen.
moves.11. Bxf6: It seems my opponent goes for the d-pawn.
moves.11... Bxf6: I leave the pawn en pris because taking it just helps me.
moves.12. Rxd6: There is a direct line winning the exchange plus keeping the pressure towards the queenside.
moves.13... Be7: Taking away the squares of the rook.
moves.14. Rd4: Wrongly trying to keep the exchange. I guess, 14. Rhd1 was way better.
moves.15. Bxf7+: Instead of giving the rook white correctly gives the bishop and causes some stir.
moves.16. Qf3+: The maneuver to save the rook and frighten me with a brief queen - king vis-à-vis.
moves.16... Bf6: Usually I never keep a piece (especially the king) opposite an attacker, but here opting for blocking with the bishop seems better.
moves.17. Rd3: Saving the rook and preparing to double along the d-file.
moves.17... Rf8: Preparing castling by hand and leaving the rook face to face with white's queen.
moves.18... Rb8: Alright. Time to go from defence to attack. The little struggle around the poisoned d-pawn actually decided the game. I am up one piece for two pawns and in an excellent attacking position.
moves.19. Rhd1: The d-file is "lost" for sure. But my play will be along the b-file anyway.
moves.20. h4: Attacking my kingside is way too slow. I'd go for tense defending moves only.
moves.21. h5: This is useless. All white's power is along the d-file(, where is nothing to attack).
moves.21... h6: This does not only stop white's h-pawn from advancing, it also sets up a lethal attack with my dark-squared bishop along the c1/g5-diagonal.
moves.22. Rd3d6: White makes use of the d-file by finally attacking something. (The e6-bishop.) But this allows a beautiful finish. Did he say "finish"? Yes, finish. Can you spot it? I either win further material with keeping tense pressure or checkmate. I am luckily allowed the latter.
moves.22... Bg5+: My first move of a sequence to drive the king to the vulnerable b-file and control c1.
moves.23. Kb1: I guess, 23. R6d2 was better. Can you spot the lethal attack?
moves.23... Rxb2+: Here it comes - a classic tin opener. Standard shot. Everything is forced now.
moves.24... Rb8+: The next cannon comes into play.
moves.26. Rb1: This must be prevented. But only 26. Rd8+ parting with further material would have accomplished this. 26. Rb1 leads to checkmate.
moves.26... Rxb1+: Check. Both answers to this don't defend. My three pieces left threaten checkmate on two squares.
moves.27. Kxb1 Qc1#:
Thank you! 
With my e6-bishop en pris and the other two pieces giving checkmate this makes a nice picture.
